titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Wrote in the forenoon to Mr: Murray and Mr: Bourne— Sent likewise to Van Cleef.— Evening at the Countess Eichstätt’s— Whist with Madame de Zastrow, The Minister Schrötter, and Mr: Livingstone— Came away at 9. and supped at Dr: Brown’s, where I found Mr: Arbuthnot.

2. Forenoon spent as usual— At the Queen’s Court in the Evening, and previously at the Grande Maitresse’s. Whist with Played at Casino, with the Princess Radziwill, Madame de Heinitz, and the Baron de Hardenberg. The Baron played against the Princess, and purposely lost, which his partner discovered, and was all the time scolding him about it.— The Baron threw all the fault upon his ill play; and said that whatever people might say about Casino, he was sure there was a certain finesse in the game that he did not understand. The Princess appeared unwell, and much out of spirits— Since the disgrace which befell her husband, he is treated with so little respect or attention that it must very much mortify her; and she perceives the effects of it in the deportment of the Court towards herself.— The king spoke to me of a young man here by the name of Washington, and enquired, whether he was a relation of the General— He enquired also what was the shortest time in which a passage between Europe and America, could be performed.— Mrs: Adams was invited and stayed to supper

3. At the Casino before dinner.— Evening with Mrs: Adams at Countess Brühl’s— The Count was not at home— We found Mr: Livingstone there, but he soon went away. Baron Alvensleben and Mr: Perponcher, were also there great part of the Evening.— We had some music— The Countess Mary Brühl played on the Piano forte. Miss Brown and Mrs Adams sung.— Alvensleben very fond of music— He is a ghost-seer too— Mr: Livingstone amused himself with a story A. had told him, about a vision of three beautiful women appearing on the wall of his bed-chamber &c &c.— A Minister of State!— But the thing is very common here— Scarce an individual of the royal family, but firmly believes in ghosts, and apparitions, and all the farrago of witchcraft— Successors of Frederic 2!—

4. Miss Emily Zeunert, called just after dinner and paid a visit to Mrs: Adams.— I went to see the English Prince Augustus, but he was so ill that he could receive no company— Evening at the play— Saw Benjowsky, or the conspiracy at Kamschatka—of Kotzebue— An interesting Comedy—but very bad in point of moral— And the characters are too much in extremes.— Stepanoff is the best drawn.— After returning home, read a little of Gillies.

5. Mrs: Adams went this afternoon to pay a visit to the Countess Neale, upon her return to town, with the Princess Ferdinand.— Began this day upon an answer to the last note from the Cabinet Ministers.— Evening at home.
6. Spent this day and Evening again at home. Letters this Evening from the Secretary of State, Mr: King, and Mr: Pitcairn; and at noon from Mr: Murray.

7. Called upon Prince Augustus this afternoon, and found him at home— He is well informed upon the current topics of the time, and discovers much moderation in his sentiments.— Afterwards went to see Count Haugwiz by appointment. He told me he had a double regret in having been obliged to delay so long an answer to my application for permission to export arms; and that at last the answer is not such as he could wish. The permission cannot be granted because the king’s own troops, will want all that the manufacture can produce for a year to come.— I had likewise considerable conversation with him upon the ministerial answer to my last note— He agreed to every thing— It is his universal practice always to say yes—but I have learnt by constant experience that there is not the smallest dependence to be placed upon what he says.— I never have relied upon him, for he has, a Mirabeau says of the Duke of Brunswic, une grande reputation de fausseté—and never was reputation more merited— He concurred this time so decisively in every objection I made, that I much question whether my his next official answer, will yield in any one point— I shall soon try— He appeared very much irritated against the french government, and spoke in particular about their late decree, to treat as Pirates all neutral subjects in the English or Russian naval service, who may fall into their hands, with a bitterness, which in another man would have been an evidence of sincerity.— I believe he is in truth dissatisfied with France, just at this moment.— But she can whistle him back, when she pleases.— Evening at a Ball, at the Minister Heinitz’s— The king, queen and royal family all there— No supper— Party over at about ten.

8. Evening party at the Princess de Sachen’s— Mrs: A. did not go, but went to Mrs: Brown’s.— Reversi with Made de Hagen—Marquis de Musquiz, and M. de Wulsknitz— Siéyés has produced a great change in the politics of Musquiz, who is now little better than a mere frenchman— Did not stay to supper, but went to Dr: Brown’s, where I found Count Brühl, with his family; and General Descars, a french emigrant: but in the Prussian service. Very talkative—but it is to be hoped he knows more about military science than poetry— He said he had known Germans who thought Klopstock superior to all the Poets in the world— And that such Poets as Homer, and Milton and Newton, were nothing, in comparison with him— Count Brühl is a great musician, and performs remarkably well upon the violin.

9. Ball, this Evening at the Queen’s.— The Queen mother is come home and was present.— Whist with Madame de Voss, Baron d’Engström and Counta Gens d’arme I believe— We came away before supper; but the Ball was continued untill the morning.

10. Dined at Doctor Brown’s with Prince Augustus, and the English company now here.— The Prince said if he ever had any money of his own he would settle for life at Naples, where he enjoys better health than elsewhere. He has a Doctor Domeyer with him from the University of Gottingen, in whom he places great confidence. He made many enquiries concerning the yellow fever, and said he was not satisfied with any of the publications upon the subject that came from America— Not even with that of Doctor Rush, who had shewn distinguished talents in other works, but who on this occasion had not reasoned at-all with a philosophic mind. He appeared fully convinced that if he were in America, there would be no such thing as yellow fever, or that all its malignity would vanish before his medical skill.— At dinner he took Lord Talbot to task, for drinking heating, inflammatory wines, which he told him would shorten his life &c— We had music after dinner.— Came home at about 8, and passed the remainder of the Evening by ourselves.
11. Mr: Washington and Mr: Perponcher called in the afternoon, and took tea with us.— Finished my first draft of a reply to the ministerial notes I have lately received.— Read Gillies.

12.— Visit from Mr: Engeström this morning.— Came to enquire whether the United States would wish to purchase the island of St. Bartholomew.— At the Casino this Evening.— Finished the third volume of Gillies.

13. The English Prince Augustus and his family, Lord Talbot, Dr: Brown and his family, Mr: Garlike, the two Barons Ompteda, and Mr: Sloper dined with us.— The party very agreeable— The last part of the Evening, we were at Baron Alvensleben’s ball— The king asked me if there were many Poles now in America. Weather extremely cold.

14. Weather continues excessively cold.— Chief part of the Evening at the Casino— Remainder at Dr: Brown’s, where we found Count and Countess Bruhl and their daughters.— The Count told us a number of anecdotes of the seven years war when he was in the french army, and of the campaign of 1793 when he was with the Duke of Brunswic in Champagne—shewing the propensity of all soldiers to pillage.

15. Weather moderated at length.— Visit to Madame de Goudi, the grande maitresse of the Queen mother— She is ill, and did not see us.— To Madame de Sartoris, who was not at home.— At the supper party at Count Schulenburg’s where were an immense crowd of People— We stayed not long, but passed the rest of the Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Had some conversation with General Tempelhoff, and Major Wortenberg.— Whist with the Comte Redern, Comte Bronikowki and Mr: Helbig.— The second is a Pole recently from Paris, who told us much of the manners and tone of Society prevailing there.— We came away before supper.

16. At Court this Evening, where I heard of the french declaration of War against the kings of Naples & Sardinia. The last quite unexpected.— Whist with Mlle: de Viereck, Madameand Mr:Called at Doctor Brown’s, as I came home—found Mrs: A. there.— Heard this Evening of the Death of my Cousin E Shaw, and of my friend T. Crafts.— My Cousin’s was not unexpected.— Poor Crafts was the delight of his friends— A man of original and peculiar humour, and a disposition that gave a charm to all convivial parties where he was.— I shall always remember him with tenderness, and regret his early death.— He was of my own age, or my junior by a year.

17. Dined with Lord Talbot, at the Hotel de Russie, in the same apartment where I witnessed and was part of such a distressing seen, but a year ago.— Prince Augustus and his Gentlemen, with his two newly arrived friends Brummell and Graves, and the other English now here, were the company, together with the Comte de St: George, a Swiss Gentleman.— The dinner was lively and gay, more than suited my temper of mind— They sung several songs, which brought poor Crafts painfully to my mind, and which I have scarcely heard since the time when I associated most with him.— When I came home, I found the eldest Miss Brown’s with Mrs: Adams, and they with Mr Richards passed the Evening with us.

18. Busily engaged in writing all the forenoon, and after dinner. Miss E. Zeunert at tea.— Count & Countess Brühl, and their eldest daughter, passed the Evening here— The Count is a son of the famous Saxon Minister Count Brühl, so known for his animosity against Frederic II— Yet this one, was Governor of the present king, and is now a General of Cavalry.— The Countess is the daughter of an English Banker who was settled at Amsterdam, by the name of Gom.

19. Mrs: Adams dined with the Queen mother.— Evening party and supper at Monsr: de Massow’s.— Whist with Madame de Saldern, Madame the Chancellor Goldbeck and M: d’Aguilar, a Portuguese Gentleman, and relation to the Vicomte d’Anadia.— Did not stay to supper.— Called at Dr: Brown’s for Mrs: A—as I came home.

20. Mr: Garlike called on me this forenoon, and had some conversation with me upon the present State of affairs: read me one of his late dispatches.— Visit from Mr: Gorman, an English Gentleman, who brought me a letter of Introduction from my brother, whom he met at Hamburg.— Evening at Baron Alvensleben’s ball; from which, we went as engaged, to Prince Ferdinand’s— But the Princess unwilling to deprive Mrs: A. of the pleasure of dancing, desired us to return to the Ball, which we did— Danced one dance with Miss Brühl.

21. Mr: Gorman, Mr: Livingston and Mr: Garlike dined with us— Mrs: Adams went with Madame d’Engeström to be introduced to Madame de Rosenkranz.— Most of the Evening at the Casino. Then called at Dr: Brown’s for Mrs: A. and supped there.

22. Snowed all day, so that I could not walk out.— Evening party and supper at the Grand Marshall Count Podewils’s— Mrs: A. did not go.— Whist with Madame de Saldern, Madame de Heinitz and M. d’Aguilar—did not stay to supper.— I called at 1/2 past five upon Count Haugwitz, and gave him my reply to the last answer of the Cabinet Ministry, concerning the Treaty. He desired me to leave it with him, and call again on Monday at the same hour.— He appeared very much exasperated against the french Government; especially on account of their late declaration of War against the king of Sardinia.

23. Mr: Gorman called at about 2.— I went and introduced him at the Casino.— Walk in the Park. At Court in the Evening. Mrs: A. did not go.— The weather, which very suddenly grew extremely cold in the course of the day, furnished a subject of conversation both to the king and queen. Whist with Madame de Kunheim, Madame de Rosiere, and Mr: Armin de Suckow

24. The Weather excessively cold.— Walked however before dinner in the Park.— at 1/2 past 5. called again upon Count Haugwitz, who returned me my note and desired me to present it— He said that it must again be referred to the commercial department; but he believed there would be no difficulty in coming to an arrangement, and for his own part, he was personally altogether of my opinion, upon the points mentioned in the note— He afterwards told me the Government had received this day a communication that the french had made themselves masters of Turin, seized the king, and sent him to Sardinia, and established a provisional Government in Piedmont.— The Count talked with too much bitterness upon this business.— “Infamous conduct—unexampled perfidy—senseless policy,” and many other epithets equally harsh he applied without scruple or measure to the french Government on this occasion. I have no doubt he is very angry, and will be glad to see Austria go to War for it—but then he will come back to the favourite system of neutrality.— At home the remainder of the Evening— Lord Talbot called on us.

25. Mr: Gorman and William Brown called upon us this forenoon. Went at 1/2 past 12 to Count Finkenstein, and delivered to him, my third Note, concerning the renewal of the Treaty— He told me that it would be necessary to concert with Mr: Struensée, who is at the head of the commercial department, before I could have an answer; but he was generally expeditious, and our arrangements might be made without further difficulty. The old Count is not so lavish of his word as his colleague Haugwitz, and I place more dependance upon what he says.— He spoke of my application for permission to export muskets, and said that it was much regretted, that the necessities of the king’s own troops would not allow him to give the permission.— Evening at Doctor Brown’s— Count Brühl and his family, Lord Talbot, Mr: Garlike, Mr: Gorman, & Miss Bishopswerder were there— We danced, part of the Evening.— Weather cold in extreme— Réaumur’s thermometer 19 below 0.

26. Weather continues excessively cold, though rather less than yesterday.— Evening party and supper at Madame de Bredow’s.— Mrs: A. did not go. The Miss Brown’s, and Mr: Arbuthnot, passed the evening with her. Whist with Madame de Marwitz; Mlle: de Hagen, and M. de Zastrow—did not stay to supper.— Conversation with M. d’Aguilar, who is sensible, though aukward in his manners.

27. Weather continues to moderate; though still very cold— Letter from Mr: Murray—mentions the Death of Miss Westcott and Miss Breck— Letter likewise from Pitcairn.— Evening at Baron Alvensleben’s ball. The king unwell, and was not there— The queen went away early.— Reversi with Madame de Hagen, Madame de Pannewitz and Count Goltz.— Home at ten.
28. Went to a concert this afternoon at the Ville de Paris, to hear an instrument of new Invention. found it very indifferent. Met M. and Madame de Bacounin there.

29. Rose this morning very unwell, and continued so the whole day. Dined however at Count Finkenstein’s. About 20 persons in the company. A Colonelson in Law of the old Count, was very conversible, but I could not much attend to him— Home immediately after dinner.— Could not go in the Evening either to Count Redern’s party or to Prince Ferdinand’s— Mrs: A. went to make my excuse at the last. Dr: Brown called on me in the Evening.

30. Find myself quite recovered, but did not go out this day.— There was no Court, both the king and queen being unwell. Doctor Brown called again this morning. Read as customary in the forenoon, and some of Pope’s poetry in the evening— Received Letters from the Secy: of State—from Mr: King, & from Pitcairn.

31. Walk in the park before dinner.— Ball in the Evening, given by Lord Talbot, to a small party, at the Hotel de Russie.— We danced till two in the morning. The supper very elegant.— Prince Augustus there; and stayed very late.— Finished Buchholz. 2. Vol: this morning.

Day.— The forenoon, the same as the months past— The only difference of the Evening is that now we have scarcely one from one end of the month to the other, without some engagement in company.— This kind of life so contrary to that which my inclination would dictate, is unavoidable— The year has not in any respect been a profitable one to me— The only acquisition of any value that it has afforded is that of reading German very indifferently.
